_prev_prog_3.Description: Express Cooling has implemented the Risk Management Program (RMP) at the Salinas, California facility in order to comply with regulations and also to fulfill this Facilities responsibility to protect its employees, equipment, property, the surrounding community, and the environment from accidental releases of Anhydrous Ammonia.  The purpose of the RMP is to reduce and minimize the occurrence and the consequences of releases of Anhydrous Ammonia from the refrigeration process.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.    EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
[40 CFR 68.155/CALARP 2745.3]
1.    Purpose
The purpose of the RMP is to reduce and minimize the occurrence and the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process. This section summarizes the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk of a hazardous materials release.
American Growers Cooling Company will utilize current and appropriate engineering practices to inspect refrigeration equipment prior to startup and during operations. These procedures identify potential sources of release and subsequent equipment corrections required to prevent these releases. Onsite personnel and certified refrigeration contractors regularly inspect the equipment, as required.
2.    Description of Source and Substance Handled
The American Growers Cooling Company facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia in their produce and cold storage operations. The refrigeration plant is comprised of one stationary process that provides refrigeration for cold rooms, portable vacuum cooling, pressure cooling and ice manufacturing. Produce is brought to the facility where it is pre-cooled and stored for processing and shipment. Produce includes a variety of field pack produce products.
Ammonia is the only listed material used at this facility. The plant operates with a total charge of approximately 33,500 lbs. of ammonia distributed throughout the facility. 
The ammonia charge is contained primarily in the high pressure receivers and the low pressure pump receivers. The remainder of the refrigerant is contained within the piping and the refrigeration coils.  
 Ammonia Refrigeration
The refrigeration system is a single stage vapor compression cycle. In general, the process chemistry is as follows:
1.    Low pressure vapor is compressed to high pressure gas by refrigeration compressors.
2.    High pressure vapor is condensed to high pressure liquid by the evaporative condenser.  Condensation occurs because of heat rejection to ambient resulting from

the evaporation of water sprayed on the condenser coil.
3.    High pressure liquid gravity feeds from the condenser to the high pressure receiver where it is stored until needed.
4.    High pressure ammonia is fed from the high pressure receiver to the low pressure vessels.  This is made possible by the pressure differential between the two types of vessels.  Pressure is dropped when the liquid passes though an expansion device located between the high and low pressure vessels.
5.    The evaporators are recirculation types where low pressure liquid is pumped from low pressure receiver. The evaporators are room coils for maintaining cold room or freezer storage temperatures.
6.    Evaporation of the low pressure liquid occurs due to warmer air coming in contact with the evaporators. The evaporation produces the cooling effect.  
A mixture of liquid and vapor is returned to the low pressure vessel. Low pressure vapor is drawn off by the compressors and the liquid is circulated back through the room coils. The refrigeration system consists of the following equipment
A?    Seven compressors
A?    Three low pressure receivers
A?    Three high pressure receivers 
A?    Seven fixed evaporative cooling condensers
A?    Room cooling evaporators
A?    A diffusion system
A?    Automatic controls for the individual systems 
The Ammonia Refrigeration Safety Inspection (IIAR) Checklists, included in the document binder, describe equipment details. A complete set of system drawings is also included in the document binder. 
Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is a gas in its natural state and is extremely irritating to mucous membranes and lung tissue. The gas is pungent and may cause suffocation, as shortness of breath and labored breathing can develop if inhaled. Prolonged inhalation of high concentrations may cause bronchitis and/ or pneumonia, with some residual reduction in pulmonary functions. Repeated or prolonged contact of high concentrations of ammonia to the skin can cause frostbite, redness, pain, and serious ski

n burn. A Material Safety Data sheet (MSDS) for ammonia is included in the document binder. Written in both Spanish and English, the MSDS details the chemical properties and health hazards of anhydrous ammonia.
3.    Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
American Growers Cooling Company has implemented the Risk Management Plan (RMP) at the Salinas, California facility in order to comply with the regulations, and to fulfill this facilityA?s responsibility to protecting its employees, equipment, property, the surrounding community, and the environment from accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.
The purpose of the RMP is to reduce and minimize the occurrence and the consequences of releases of anhydrous ammonia from the refrigeration process. The following summarizes the programs, policies, and procedures in place to reduce the risk of a hazardous materials release.
4.    Accidental Release Prevention Program
The program consists of pre-startup inspection, emergency response, and regular training. A thorough review of the system including a Process Hazards Analysis (PHA or Hazop) was performed in 2000, and re-validated for this RMP. Equipment corrections and updates were made for those items determined to have the highest potential for offsite releases.  
Safety and equipment operational training is conducted on a yearly basis and will include equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of Business Response Procedures, and evacuation procedures. Additional items requiring further review, correction, and/or updating will be identified. Refrigeration equipment will be reviewed and the RMP will be updated when changes to equipment occur or when new equipment is brought on-site. 
American Growers Cooling Company maintains an accidental release prevention program to eliminate or minimize releases. The program includes equipment monitoring, regular inspections and maintenance, and log keeping of (1) operating conditions, (2) scheduled main

tenance, (3) emergency response, and (4) operator training. 
The operations at this facility are seasonal with operations occurring primarily between the months of April through October during the produce growing season. The equipment is inspected during the off-season and any repairs or change outs are made at this time. This off-season time is used to prepare the equipment for non-stop operation during the season.
The refrigeration system is monitored and controlled by an Andover computer control system. This system monitors the refrigeration process parameters and the system ammonia leak detectors. Each on-call operator carries a pager. The operators will be paged by the Andover system in the event of out of specification system operation or on the detection of an ammonia release.
Operators and onsite personnel provide initial emergency response. Onsite personnel will make a preliminary assessment in the event of a release and will provide first response. First response may include emergency equipment shutdown, system isolation, or controlled operation such as pump down to prevent or reduce an offsite release. Local fire and police departments will provide emergency response for a major release event with mutual aide response from on-site personnel. Emergency contact information is included in the document binder.
Emergency response training will be conducted yearly for current employees and as required for new employees. Records will be kept of all training performed at the site for a minimum of five (5) years. 
Safety
The ammonia refrigeration operation system has specific safety measures in place to prevent accidental release. Operators and mechanics are trained for safe operation and maintenance of the refrigeration system. They are also trained in emergency response procedures in the event of an ammonia release. An alarm and detection system monitors the refrigeration machinery room and process areas for unsafe ammonia concentration levels and for operating

conditions outside of safety set points. Monitoring is 24 hours per day. All relief valves are tied into an ammonia diffusion tank, allowing system pressures to be relieved without releasing to ambient.
Hazard Analyses
A thorough review of the refrigeration system including a What If hazard analysis was performed. This analysis is included in Appendix E.  
Training
Safety and equipment operational training will be conducted on a yearly basis and will include equipment operational procedures, emergency response procedures, review of general Risk Management Plan procedures, review of the Emergency Response Plan, and evacuation procedures. Training documentation is included in the document binder.
Updates
As required, Updates, refrigeration equipment will be inspected and reviewed periodically and as new equipment becomes operational onsite. This RMP, which includes accident prevention procedures for the ammonia refrigeration system, is maintained onsite. 
5.    Five-Year Accident History
No reportable releases or accidents relating to the release of ammonia have occurred at the facility in the last five years. Releases of ammonia, should they occur, will be responded to in accordance with company policy and the procedures outlined in this RMP.
6.    Emergency Response Program
American Growers Cooling Company has implemented the State and County mandated emergency response plan (Business Response Plan.) This plan outlines procedures for emergency ammonia release response, as well as general response.
In event of a release, certain personnel are designated to determine the potential hazard and coordinate response procedures. The emergency coordinator is responsible for contacting emergency response agencies, schools, daycare centers, and acute care facilities that may be affected by the release. The coordinator will also be responsible for evacuation of employees if necessary and for coordination with community emergency responders if offsite evacuations are required.
The eme

rgency response program consists of the following elements:
A?    Contact phone numbers for emergency coordinator and emergency contacts
A?    Notification procedures
A?    Hazardous material incident response to ammonia releases and other incidents
A?    Coordinator and personnel responsibilities
A?    Releases to be reported
A?    Evacuation plans
A?    Emergency response checklist
A?    Emergency shutdown procedures
A?    Emergency response training
7.    Planned Safety Improvements
Safety improvements have been identified during the preparation of this program. These improvements have been documented and a schedule developed for their implementation. Some of these improvements include installation of seismic restraints, change out of pressure relief valves 5 years or older, and development of operational procedures. Additional safety improvements may be identified during the upcoming PHA revalidation.
